climbs.name: W.A.P. (Wet Ass Pitch)
climbs.fa: Equipped by: Chase Webb FA: Judith Brown

content.description: This section of the wall tends to be very wet but is certainly worthwhile if you can catch it dry! The first half of the climb features awesome technical climbing in excellent dark rock. Just past midway the terrain steepens and the rock quality goes down, however, the rock is more solid than it appears! Unique for Mag, as the climb goes all the way to the top of the cliff making it one of the taller pitches in the area.
content.location: Look for the dirty black hand crack as you make your way past the Breakfast Wall. The climb is located just to the right of the crack or down and right from the famous (now dead) Mount Magazine State Park tree.

content.description: Dihedral climb with a traversing crux move.  Ends at the anchors of Bit's n' Pieces.
content.location: Climb the corner crack on the right side of the Breakfast Wall.

climbs.name: Thriller
climbs.fa: FA: Paul Holland & Kevin Short.  FFA: Eric Forney

content.description: Not the best climb at Mag, but probably the best hard trad line.Cruise up easy terrain to the base of the roof, which is easier than it looks.  Use some body english to get established in the crack on the face above.  Fire in some gear, and punch it through a tough section to a rest.  Then finish on easier terrain.
content.protection: A single rack should suffice.  The book says a #4 camalot is optional, but there is a perfect .75 placement a foot higher, so it seems unnecessary.  Save a .5 for the top.
content.location: Keep an eye out for a body length roof, split by a handcrack, at a height of 15 feet.

content.description: Heady line on this beautiful wall that climbs the thin seam through a small roof that hosts the crux. Easier climbing to a bolt before traversing right to the shared anchors.
content.protection: 1 bolt, SR to a #3 Camelot, micro wires!
content.location: Begins in front of the detached boulder (on the furthest right side of the boulder). Climb should follow the seam, through the right side of the roof, small traverse right to clip a bolt, continue up then further right traverse to the shared anchors.

climbs.name: This is Where the Fun Starts

content.description: Unique crack system variation that stems off of Seam of Dreams.
content.location: Climb follows Seam of Dreams before peeling off right about half way through.

climbs.name: Seam of Dreams
climbs.fa: Kevin Short, Paul Holland, John Wilson

content.description: Bold climb through a thin seam.
content.protection: wires & doubles of small gear to a .5 cam, bolted anchor
content.location: Begins in the black rock about 10 feet right of the detached boulder.

content.description: Don't let social distancing get you down. Start in a flake system then move left to pull the roof at the second bolt. But you haven't flattened the curve just yet. Sneeze into your elbow pit as you decipher the best way to get to the third bolt. A fall here could put you within 6 feet of your belayer. If you're nice you'll leave an extended draw there for the next leader - just make sure to wash your hands for 20 seconds first. Then enjoy the milder but fun face climbing before reaching the anchors just under the roof.
content.protection: 5 bolts to a 2 bolt anchor. CDC recommendations: N97 respirator, rubber gloves, soap & water.
content.location: Start in a left-facing flake system in the small corridor created by a free-standing boulder. Follow what is currently the only line of bolts on the wall. Just climber's right of Moonlight Direct.

content.description: Scramble up to a large ledge and run it out to a small left-facing dihedral and move up to a second ledge.  Step right and into the larger, more defined dihedral.  The rock quality on this pitch is rather marginal.  Shares anchors with Jupiter Tremble

Start under a roof. Clip a bolt. Move around the roof to the right clipping three more bolts (10a).  

  After the fourth bolt, climb up the arete on easy terrain with no gear (5.7). After 20 feet you will hit a crack. Plug in some pieces. Fun crack finish. Shares anchors with Moonlight Stroll.
content.protection: 4 bolts (Rebolted Winter 2020). A few medium sized cams. There is a solid BD #2 placement. Bolted anchor.
content.location: Begins around the corner climber's left of Moonlight Stroll.

content.description: Shares the first half with Multi-Colored Poptart, then moves right onto a thin and beautiful face.
content.location: Left side of the breakfast wall.

content.description:
Stem up between boulder and main wall. climb up and traverse left below roof for 15 feet to small crack to anchors 

  Shares anchors with 3 other climbs (Ticket To Fly, Bits in Pieces, and Nymphomaniac). Anchors located on the left hand side of roof. 

  Has second optional pitch which climbs to top (tree anchor).
Good quality clean 5.9 route with well placed bolts.  New set of anchors more direct with the bolt line added in summer of 2017.
content.location: Left most route on the Breakfast Wall.

content.description: Add some spice to Moonlight Stroll by doing this techy & thin start into the classic, hand jam finish!
content.protection: Standard single rack for the crack & a #6 or #7 nut for the thin seam (recommend to place this from the ground). Anchors up top.
content.location: Begin just in front of the large boulder that you encounter when walking East.  This climb is just right of the Nymphomaniac arete.  Use the thin seam as your guide and head straight up!

content.description: Start as for Over Easy, but step left at the second ledge and work up and left into a small left-facing corner and the first bolt.  Crux moves at the end of the corner to gain the easier finish.  Save a #1 Camalot for the horizontal after the last bolt.
content.protection: 4 bolts, rack to #1 Camalot.  Bolt anchor

content.description: Easy climbing to the first bolt leads into a technical sequence past three bolts. From here pull a large tricky roof (crux), then another smaller roof brings you to the anchors.
content.location: Near the large corner on the right end of the Breakfast Wall. Look for the three, "V" shaped roofs.

content.description: Climbs a thin crack into a right facing dihedral with challenging moves.
content.location: Start to the right of the black rock.

climbs.name: Eggspecting
climbs.fa: Equipper: Chase Webb F.A.: Judith Brown

content.description: Climb easy terrain to a ledge met by the first bolt. From here, layback and stem your way to the second bolt and transition onto the face to crank out some thin face climbing and a difficult 3rd clip. Cool holds and features will lead you to a showstopper crux at the last bolt, just before the anchors. Named for the Snake Farms newest member (Baby Wall A.K.A. Hattie A.K.A. destroyer of sleep)!
content.location: Look for the grey bulge that leads to cool undercling flakes in brighter rock. Currently the leftmost route on the breakfast wall.

content.description: Pull a small roof to a high first bolt. A balancy move brings you to an arete feature, this leads to more holds and the top. I don' think anyone had been on this climb in years, the key hold at the top was completely covered in spongy moss, I gave it a good cleaning and believe this is a worth-while climb that deserves more traffic.
content.location: Near the large corner towards the right end of the Breakfast Wall.

content.description: Although a little too late for breakfast, this is a quality new addition to the wall. Climb easier terrain to a high first bolt and follow the orange streaked arete past a small roof. Above the roof, the difficulty eases off. Shares anchors with "Multi-Colored Poptart."
content.location: Look for the orange streaked arete just left of "Multi-Colored Poptart." Currently the leftmost route on the breakfast wall.

content.description: Sustained climbing on solid rock! This route looks short but can feel like it goes on forever as you make spicy moves above bolts!  Keep your head game together to pull the final crux move over the ledge.  Bring a few pieces to protect the fun, stemming, crack climb to the anchors.
content.protection: 2 bolts (rebolted 2020) + anchor & a single rack (#.5 through a #2).
content.location: An obvious flat face to the let of a dihedral (Ticket to Fly) & right of an arete (Nymphomaniac).

content.description: The obvious red wall.  Sandstone rock, pretty decent quality.  Often secluded.  These are bolted sport climbs in the 5.7 to 5.11d range.
